summary: This document is an email chain from March 2016, forwarded in 2019, discussing a meeting request to discuss a potential sex trafficking case against Jeffrey Epstein. The initial email describes a pitch from lawyers representing a victim and outlines the complex legal background, including Epstein's 2007 non-prosecution agreement.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Described as a financier with multiple homes, accused of sex trafficking with dozens of victims, and subject of a 2007 non-prosecution agreement with the Southern District of Florida USAO.

persons.name: Pete Skinner
persons.context: One of the lawyers who, along with two others, pitched a sex trafficking case against Jeffrey Epstein to the recipient's office.

connections.description: Skinner and two other lawyers pitched a sex trafficking case against Epstein on behalf of a victim.

events.title: Epstein's non-prosecution agreement
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein entered into a non-prosecution agreement with the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida.

events.title: Lawyer pitch on Epstein case
events.description: Pete Skinner and two other lawyers pitched a sex trafficking case against Jeffrey Epstein to the recipient's office, representing a victim who claims to have been prostituted by Epstein at age 16.

keyFacts: In March 2016, lawyers including Pete Skinner pitched a sex trafficking case against Jeffrey Epstein to the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York.
The case involved a victim who claimed to have been prostituted by Epstein when she was 16 years old.
The email states Epstein 'apparently had dozens of victims' and it was unclear if his criminal conduct had stopped.
The email references Epstein's 2007 non-prosecution agreement with the Southern District of Florida USAO as a complicating factor.
The document indicates ongoing legal interest and potential investigation into Epstein's activities by federal prosecutors in New York as of 2016.
